pr_title: Adding functionality to create a manifest list from a list of built images

timeline.message: Adding fnctionality to build a manifest list

Fix child progress dispatcher factory (#2699)

* Fixing concurrent progress dispatcher

* Removing un-related changes

* Add multiple progress dispatchers for concurrent build processes

* Progress Dispatcher Fix
Commit for debugging Java I/O error
Extending Jib to support multiple archs
Return the one platform specification restriction

timeline.bodyHTML:
Put everything into the try-resources block.

  try (TimerEventDispatcher ...) {
    ...
    return new ManifestListGenator(...);
  }

And actually, I think we can use

BlobDescriptor configDescriptor = Digests.computeDigest(containerConfig);

instead of Blobs.from(...).writeTo(). I am not sure why we used it that way in other places.

And I think we can simply this to

    if (builtImages.size() == 1) {
      ImageToJsonTranslator imageTranslator = new ImageToJsonTranslator(builtImages.get(0));
      BlobDescriptor configDescriptor =
          Digests.computeDigest(imageTranslator.getContainerConfiguration());
      return imageTranslator.getManifestTemplate(buildContext.getTargetFormat(), configDescriptor);
    }

    return new ManifestListGenerator(...);
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.body:
This is confusing

```suggestion
            () ->
              new BuildManifestListStep(
                      buildContext,
                      childProgressDispatcherFactory,
                      realizeFutures(results.builtImagesAndBaseImages.get().keySet()))
                  .call());
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This is confusing

Suggested change
() -> {
List<Future<Image>> builtImages = new ArrayList<>();
builtImages.addAll(results.builtImagesAndBaseImages.get().keySet());
return new BuildManifestListStep(
buildContext, childProgressDispatcherFactory, realizeFutures(builtImages))
.call();
});
() ->
new BuildManifestListStep(
buildContext,
childProgressDispatcherFactory,
realizeFutures(results.builtImagesAndBaseImages.get().keySet()))
.call());
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText:
We need to convert the keySet() to an ArrayList before using the realizeFutures .
 new BuildManifestListOrSingleManifestStep(
                        buildContext,
                        childProgressDispatcherFactory,
                        realizeFutures(
                            new ArrayList<>(results.builtImagesAndBaseImages.get().keySet())))
                    .call());

This might be better
replies.author: louismurerwa
chanseokoh

timeline.message:
Create manifest list test chanseok (#2706)

* Clean up code

* Rename test methods

Co-authored-by: Chanseok Oh <chanseok@google.com>

timeline.bodyHTML:
Javadoc comments (starting with /** using double asterisks) are basically for machine processing to generate a nice-looking manual for external users using a library. This is an internal code comment, so we should use // code comment. And no HTML formatting, and no need to follow the Javadoc convention. I also suggest proper indentation for readability.

// Expected manifest JSON:
// {
//   "schemaVersion":2,
//   "mediaType":"application/vnd.docker.distribution.manifest.v2+json",
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Yes this is the issue I was asking about in the meeting.I'l remove the java doc format and use code comments instead.

timeline.body:
I see we always create a Docker manifest list, which is another limitation of multi-platform image building. Note that there are 2 avenues for considering OCI vs Docker format.
- Base image: we take care of this automatically, and the format is transparent to the user.
- Target image(s): user-configurable with `<format>OCI` or `<format>Docker`.

That is, Jib will be broken when `<format>OCI` is specified (because we will build OCI manifests while a Docker manifest). We should add another item to fix. Please add this to your tracking list.
timeline.bodyText:
I see we always create a Docker manifest list, which is another limitation of multi-platform image building. Note that there are 2 avenues for considering OCI vs Docker format.

Base image: we take care of this automatically, and the format is transparent to the user.
Target image(s): user-configurable with <format>OCI or <format>Docker.

That is, Jib will be broken when <format>OCI is specified (because we will build OCI manifests while a Docker manifest). We should add another item to fix. Please add this to your tracking list.
timeline.bodyHTML:
I see we always create a Docker manifest list, which is another limitation of multi-platform image building. Note that there are 2 avenues for considering OCI vs Docker format.

  • Base image: we take care of this automatically, and the format is transparent to the user.
  • Target image(s): user-configurable with <format>OCI or <format>Docker.

That is, Jib will be broken when <format>OCI is specified (because we will build OCI manifests while a Docker manifest). We should add another item to fix. Please add this to your tracking list.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Note that support OCI for target images is much more important: most registries can just convert OCI to Docker on-the-fly, so not accepting an OCI base image manifest isn't really a problem in practice. OTOH, specifying <format>OCI will outright breaking Jib image building (in the multi-platform case).
replies.author: chanseokoh

timeline.body:
Oh, we should consider the boundary condition when `images` is empty. I think it makes sense to just fail

```
Preconditions.checkState(!images.isEmpty(), "no images given");
```

and add a test for this. (It's important to test boundary conditions.) It also makes sense to add the same test in `BuildManifestListOrSingleManifestStepTest` to see if the exception is properly propagated to that level too.
timeline.bodyHTML:
Oh, we should consider the boundary condition when images is empty. I think it makes sense to just fail

Preconditions.checkState(!images.isEmpty(), "no images given");

and add a test for this. (It's important to test boundary conditions.) It also makes sense to add the same test in BuildManifestListOrSingleManifestStepTest to see if the exception is properly propagated to that level too.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: That makes sense , I was thinking about these cases from the StepsRunner standpoint. Since steps runner always ensures the !images.isEmpty()  we should be good but I am now realizing that these libraries can be called from anywhere in Jib so we actually need to check the parameters also inside the libraries themselves.
replies.author: louismurerwa

replies.bodyText: Exactly. The class is independent of StepsRunner (or anything else unrelated). And as soon as we have the class, other parts of the Jib repo will pick it up and start using it. The implementation should be self-sufficient and error-tolerant.
replies.author: chanseokoh
